page.title: 06NATURAL LIFE AROUND FELTWELL
page.content: Feltwell lies between the Fens and the Brecklands, where there is a large warren in the forest. Sometimes the rabbits escape and find their way to the allotments. They cause damage to the crops. Other mammals found in the village are mice, rats, foxes and hedgehogs. We have most common garden birds and also a few wild pheasants. Down by the new river we find herons. In the fields live owls and kestrels. The farmland around Feltwell used to be surrounded by elms. The Dutch Elm Disease killed them. The Fens used to be covered in sedge, reeds, alder and willow then farmers drained the land for farming. Now these plants only live in dykes and patches of woodland. Along Burdock Lane the landscape and vegetation have hardly changed in the last hundred years.
